| **phase_prompt** | task: {task} process text: {reviewed_process_text} Please check whether there are logic problems and format problems of activities and gateways in the process text, such as the reverse of the order of activities, unreasonable design of gateways, and wrong order of activities or branches. For the modification scheme, the specific reason for modification and the details of the modification scheme should be explained. Here's a shipping process and some examples of checking for errors, you can refer but not copy:                                                                                                         example1:    Problem: The 'receiving package' activity with id='activity2' and the exclusive gateway with id='exclusivegateway1' are in the wrong order and logic error.    Suggested modification: Move the 'receiving package' activity with id='activity2' under the branch with id='branch1' of the exclusive gateway with id='exclusivegateway1'.    Reason: After the sender chooses to pick up the package, the Courier can perform the activities of accepting the package. example2:    Problem: The activities are not a parallel relation in the parallel gateway with id='parallelgateway1'.    Suggested modification: In the parallel gateway with id='parallelgateway1', change the activities from a parallel structure to a sequential structure.    Reason: Logically, 'packing and handling packages' and 'transport and distribution packages' are not parallel relationships. example3:    Problem: The 'end of service' activity with id='activity7' and the 'sign for parcel' activity with id='activity8' are in the wrong order.    Suggested modification: Swap the position of the 'end of service' activity with id='activity7' and the 'sign for parcel' activity with id='activity8'.    Reason: Only after the recipient sign for package can the express company terminate the service. example4:    Problem: The sequence gateway with id='sequencegateway1' is incorrectly formatted.    Suggested modification: Remove the gateway label of the sequence gateway with id='sequencegateway1'.    Reason: Sequential activities need not be contained under a gateway. When making recommendations, don't forget the format of the process text: {format} Below are additional knowledge contexts to guide the process design: 1) The activity 'Provide cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies...' should be the last activity after everything else is done and before the end activity. 2) Activities related to stroke units, staffing, or hospitals in the QBP should be prioritized as the initial steps in their respective flow or branch. 3) All tests, including any type of imaging and blood tests, should be immediately interpreted by a healthcare expert. 4) Blood tests or any tests that take a long time toget results should occur concurrently with other activities unless required for a specific task, in which case they will be merged into the flow or branch of that activity. 5) Activities related to stroke units, staffing, or hospitals in the QBP should be put in a single activity. 6) Assessing airway, breathing, and circulation is called ABC testing and is ONE activity. 7) Neurological examination and imaging results are needed to Evaluate patients for endovascular therapy. However, they can be in parallel to other activities that don’ t need these results. 8) CBC, electrolytes, creatinine, glucose, INR, partial thromboplastin time, and troponin test are all types of blood tests, and they can all be in ONE blood works activity if they are at the same place of a process. 9) Anti platelet therapy has 4 general options(ASA, Clopidogrel, Extended - release Dipyridamole + Aspirin(Aggrenox), and rectal or gastric ASA if can 't swallow) and they should be indicated right after each initiation of antiplatelet therapy activity in the process.  10) Temperature reducing activities should happen in parallel. 11) The activity 'chest x-ray should not delay...' should have a skip flow as it should be skipped if not needed. 12) If activity 'should be evaluated in the ED to be considered for admission to hospital' is needed, it should happen in parallel and not in sequence. 13) When patients should be screened / assessed for diabetes, dental issues, cognitive impairment, and depression in the same part of the process, they should be merged into one activity along with forwarding the results. 14) Assessments related and needed to formulating management plan should be merged into one activity along with formulating the management plan. 15) Formulating the management plan should happen before the activities and assessments after it. 16) Between 24 - 48 hour of stroke onset IF no contradiction, mobilization is encouraged. However, in the first 24 hour it is only encouraged IF clinical judgement suggests otherwise, it is not. Please note: 1) If you think there is an error in the process text, output the error as requested. Please Just list one for me.  2) If you think there is no formatting or logical error in the process text, please just output 'There is no error in the process text.' and don't say anything else. |
| **phase_name** | GiveSuggestion |

Patients typically present at the ED, but the same practices should be followed\nat an outpatient clinic or when patients are directly admitted to acute care. The recommendations\nemphasize assessing the patient to inform clinical decision-making and determine the most\nappropriate pathway.\nModule 1 Recommended Practices \n1.1 Initial evaluation\n1.1.1 Rapid initial evaluation should be conducted for airway,\nbreathing, and circulation\n1.2 Initial examinations\n1.2.1 All patients should undergo a neurological examination to\ndetermine focal neurological deficits and assess stroke severity on a\nstandardized stroke scale (NIHSS or CNS for stroke)\n1.2.2 All patients should undergo brain imaging (CT or MRI)\nimmediately\n1.2.3 Brain imaging should be interpreted immediately by a health care\nprovider with expertise in reading CT and/or MRI\n1.2.4 All patients should undergo ECG to detect atrial fibrillation and\nother acute arrhythmias\n1.2.5 A chest x-ray should not delay assessment for thrombolysis \n1.2.6 All patients should have the following blood work:\n• CBC\n• electrolytes\n• creatinine\n• glucose\n• INR\n• partial thromboplastin time\n• troponin test (if clinically indicated)\n1.3 Assessment and early management of dysphagia\n1.3.1 All patients with stroke should be made NPO initially and have\ntheir swallowing ability screened using a simple, valid, reliable, bedside\ntesting protocol as part of their initial assessment and before initiating\noral medication, fluid, or food\n1.3.2 All patients with stroke who are not alert within the first 24 hours\nshould be monitored closely, and swallowing ability should be\nscreened when clinically appropriate\n1.3.3 Patients with stroke presenting with features indicating dysphagia\nor pulmonary aspiration should receive a full clinical assessment of\ntheir swallowing ability by a speech-language pathologist or\nappropriately trained specialist who would advise on swallowing ability\nand the required consistency of diet and fluids\n1.4 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies\n1.4.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged from the\nED, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary\nprevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)\n1.5 Triage tool for patients with TIA\n1.5.1 A standardized triage tool should be used to determine the\nappropriate location for the care of patients with TIA\n1.6 Initial examinations for TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke\n1.6.1 Patients with a TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke presenting\nwithin 48 hours of symptom onset or with fluctuating motor or speech\nsymptoms should undergo immediate vascular imaging of the neck\narteries (carotid ultrasound, CTA, or MRA) unless the patient is clearly\nnot a candidate for carotid artery revascularization\n1.6.2 All other patients (presenting beyond 48 hours) with a TIA or\nischemic stroke should undergo vascular imaging of the brain and\nneck arteries as soon as possible\n1.7 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke\nAbbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke\nManagement; CBC, complete blood count; CSBPR, Canadian Best Practices Recommendations; CNS, Canadian Neurological Scale; CT,\ncomputed tomography; CTA, computed tomography angiography; ECG, electrocardiogram; ED, emergency department; INR, international\nnormalized ratio; MRA, magnetic resonance angiography; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for\nChronic Conditions; NIHSS, National Institute of Health Stroke Scale; NPO, nil per os (nothing by mouth); SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate\nGuidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.\n\nThe following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.\n\nModule 1 Implementation Considerations\nGeneral considerations\n• Where feasible, EMS should divert patients to regional or district stroke centres if there is suspicion of stroke/TIA\n• The process for EMS prenotification of the receiving hospital about a stroke/TIA patient arrival should be better\nestablished to ensure acute stroke teams receive timely and detailed information\n• Collaboration between local EMS and institutions that provide stroke services should occur in all stroke networks across\nthe province to support quality improvement and facilitate access to stroke care\n• Ongoing education should be provided to EMS crews about the recognition of stroke/TIA symptoms and regional\nmedical redirect protocols\n• Standardized stroke/TIA assessment and treatment protocols/tools should be developed and used in all Ontario hospital\nEDs\n• Upon receiving EMS prenotification, the receiving hospital’s acute stroke team should be contacted and called to the ED\n(for appropriate patients)\n• Sufficient human resources capacity should be ensured so that patients can be diagnosed and treated in a timely\nmanner\n• To facilitate early assessment, hospital-level CTAS I or CTAS II access to diagnostic imaging should be established for\nsuspected stroke/TIA patients to facilitate early assessment\n• A referral process for rapid-assessment TIA and minor stroke units/TIA clinics and provincial stroke-prevention clinics\nshould be established in all hospitals for patients who are not admitted to hospital\n• Efforts to raise public awareness about the symptoms of stroke/TIA and when to contact 911 should continue to be\nenhanced and funded\nAbbreviations: CTAS, Canadian Triage and Acuity Scale; ED, emergency department; EMS, emergency medical services; TIA, transient\nischemic attack.', 'suggestions': '', 'format': "\nWhen the process starts, please output ''\nAn activity is represented as follows:\n\nThe exclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe parallel gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe inclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nAt the end of the process, please output ''\n\nThere are a few requirements that should be noted when generating process text:\n    1) role, action, objects and id in an activity represent the subject of the activity, the activity behavior, the items needed to perform in the activity and the activity id, respectively.\n    2) There are at least two branches within the exclusive gateway and the parallel gateway.\n    3) Activity, gateway, and branch id attributes must be unique.\n    4) When the branch in the exclusive gateway has a condition, fill the condition into the condition attribute. When the branch unconditional within the exclusive gateway, the condition attribute of the branch =''. However, all branches within a exclusive gateway can only be conditional, or both unconditional.\n    5) The branch in the parallel gateway has no condition attribute.\n    6) Each branch in the inclusive gateway must have condition.\n    7) There must be at least one activity inside the branch tag.\n    8) The activity of a sequential relation need not be represented by a gateway, that is, there is no 'sequenceGateway' label.\n"} |

| **task_prompt** | Module 1: Early Assessment This module identifies best practices for the early assessment of suspected TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke. Patients typically present at the ED, but the same practices should be followed at an outpatient clinic or when patients are directly admitted to acute care. The recommendations emphasize assessing the patient to inform clinical decision-making and determine the most appropriate pathway. Module 1 Recommended Practices  1.1 Initial evaluation 1.1.1 Rapid initial evaluation should be conducted for airway, breathing, and circulation 1.2 Initial examinations 1.2.1 All patients should undergo a neurological examination to determine focal neurological deficits and assess stroke severity on a standardized stroke scale (NIHSS or CNS for stroke) 1.2.2 All patients should undergo brain imaging (CT or MRI) immediately 1.2.3 Brain imaging should be interpreted immediately by a health care provider with expertise in reading CT and/or MRI 1.2.4 All patients should undergo ECG to detect atrial fibrillation and other acute arrhythmias 1.2.5 A chest x-ray should not delay assessment for thrombolysis  1.2.6 All patients should have the following blood work: • CBC • electrolytes • creatinine • glucose • INR • partial thromboplastin time • troponin test (if clinically indicated) 1.3 Assessment and early management of dysphagia 1.3.1 All patients with stroke should be made NPO initially and have their swallowing ability screened using a simple, valid, reliable, bedside testing protocol as part of their initial assessment and before initiating oral medication, fluid, or food 1.3.2 All patients with stroke who are not alert within the first 24 hours should be monitored closely, and swallowing ability should be screened when clinically appropriate 1.3.3 Patients with stroke presenting with features indicating dysphagia or pulmonary aspiration should receive a full clinical assessment of their swallowing ability by a speech-language pathologist or appropriately trained specialist who would advise on swallowing ability and the required consistency of diet and fluids 1.4 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies 1.4.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged from the ED, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10) 1.5 Triage tool for patients with TIA 1.5.1 A standardized triage tool should be used to determine the appropriate location for the care of patients with TIA 1.6 Initial examinations for TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke 1.6.1 Patients with a TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke presenting within 48 hours of symptom onset or with fluctuating motor or speech symptoms should undergo immediate vascular imaging of the neck arteries (carotid ultrasound, CTA, or MRA) unless the patient is clearly not a candidate for carotid artery revascularization 1.6.2 All other patients (presenting beyond 48 hours) with a TIA or ischemic stroke should undergo vascular imaging of the brain and neck arteries as soon as possible 1.7 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management; CBC, complete blood count; CSBPR, Canadian Best Practices Recommendations; CNS, Canadian Neurological Scale; CT, computed tomography; CTA, computed tomography angiography; ECG, electrocardiogram; ED, emergency department; INR, international normalized ratio; MRA, magnetic resonance angiography; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; NIHSS, National Institute of Health Stroke Scale; NPO, nil per os (nothing by mouth); SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack. The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel. Module 1 Implementation Considerations General considerations • Where feasible, EMS should divert patients to regional or district stroke centres if there is suspicion of stroke/TIA • The process for EMS prenotification of the receiving hospital about a stroke/TIA patient arrival should be better established to ensure acute stroke teams receive timely and detailed information • Collaboration between local EMS and institutions that provide stroke services should occur in all stroke networks across the province to support quality improvement and facilitate access to stroke care • Ongoing education should be provided to EMS crews about the recognition of stroke/TIA symptoms and regional medical redirect protocols • Standardized stroke/TIA assessment and treatment protocols/tools should be developed and used in all Ontario hospital EDs • Upon receiving EMS prenotification, the receiving hospital’s acute stroke team should be contacted and called to the ED (for appropriate patients) • Sufficient human resources capacity should be ensured so that patients can be diagnosed and treated in a timely manner • To facilitate early assessment, hospital-level CTAS I or CTAS II access to diagnostic imaging should be established for suspected stroke/TIA patients to facilitate early assessment • A referral process for rapid-assessment TIA and minor stroke units/TIA clinics and provincial stroke-prevention clinics should be established in all hospitals for patients who are not admitted to hospital • Efforts to raise public awareness about the symptoms of stroke/TIA and when to contact 911 should continue to be enhanced and funded Abbreviations: CTAS, Canadian Triage and Acuity Scale; ED, emergency department; EMS, emergency medical services; TIA, transient ischemic attack. |

SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate\nGuidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.\n\nThe following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.\n\nModule 1 Implementation Considerations\nGeneral considerations\n• Where feasible, EMS should divert patients to regional or district stroke centres if there is suspicion of stroke/TIA\n• The process for EMS prenotification of the receiving hospital about a stroke/TIA patient arrival should be better\nestablished to ensure acute stroke teams receive timely and detailed information\n• Collaboration between [2025-30-06 23:42:41 INFO] flask app.py did not start for online log
[2025-30-06 23:42:41 INFO] Team leader: **[Start Chat]**

[You're a process design reviewer. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer.
You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. Your main responsibilities include give suggestion to the process.
Here is a new customer's task: Module 1: Early Assessment
This module identifies best practices for the early assessment of suspected TIA or minor
(nondisabling) stroke. Patients typically present at the ED, but the same practices should be followed
at an outpatient clinic or when patients are directly admitted to acute care. The recommendations
emphasize assessing the patient to inform clinical decision-making and determine the most
appropriate pathway.
Module 1 Recommended Practices 
1.1 Initial evaluation
1.1.1 Rapid initial evaluation should be conducted for airway,
breathing, and circulation
1.2 Initial examinations
1.2.1 All patients should undergo a neurological examination to
determine focal neurological deficits and assess stroke severity on a
standardized stroke scale (NIHSS or CNS for stroke)
1.2.2 All patients should undergo brain imaging (CT or MRI)
immediately
1.2.3 Brain imaging should be interpreted immediately by a health care
provider with expertise in reading CT and/or MRI
1.2.4 All patients should undergo ECG to detect atrial fibrillation and
other acute arrhythmias
1.2.5 A chest x-ray should not delay assessment for thrombolysis 
1.2.6 All patients should have the following blood work:
• CBC
• electrolytes
• creatinine
• glucose
• INR
• partial thromboplastin time
• troponin test (if clinically indicated)
1.3 Assessment and early management of dysphagia
1.3.1 All patients with stroke should be made NPO initially and have
their swallowing ability screened using a simple, valid, reliable, bedside
testing protocol as part of their initial assessment and before initiating
oral medication, fluid, or food
1.3.2 All patients with stroke who are not alert within the first 24 hours
should be monitored closely, and swallowing ability should be
screened when clinically appropriate
1.3.3 Patients with stroke presenting with features indicating dysphagia
or pulmonary aspiration should receive a full clinical assessment of
their swallowing ability by a speech-language pathologist or
appropriately trained specialist who would advise on swallowing ability
and the required consistency of diet and fluids
1.4 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies
1.4.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged from the
ED, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary
prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)
1.5 Triage tool for patients with TIA
1.5.1 A standardized triage tool should be used to determine the
appropriate location for the care of patients with TIA
1.6 Initial examinations for TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
1.6.1 Patients with a TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke presenting
within 48 hours of symptom onset or with fluctuating motor or speech
symptoms should undergo immediate vascular imaging of the neck
arteries (carotid ultrasound, CTA, or MRA) unless the patient is clearly
not a candidate for carotid artery revascularization
1.6.2 All other patients (presenting beyond 48 hours) with a TIA or
ischemic stroke should undergo vascular imaging of the brain and
neck arteries as soon as possible
1.7 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke
Management; CBC, complete blood count; CSBPR, Canadian Best Practices Recommendations; CNS, Canadian Neurological Scale; CT,
computed tomography; CTA, computed tomography angiography; ECG, electrocardiogram; ED, emergency department; INR, international
normalized ratio; MRA, magnetic resonance angiography; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for
Chronic Conditions; NIHSS, National Institute of Health Stroke Scale; NPO, nil per os (nothing by mouth); SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate
Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.

The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.

Module 1 Implementation Considerations
General considerations
• Where feasible, EMS should divert patients to regional or district stroke centres if there is suspicion of stroke/TIA
• The process for EMS prenotification of the receiving hospital about a stroke/TIA patient arrival should be better
established to ensure acute stroke teams receive timely and detailed information
• Collaboration between local EMS and institutions that provide stroke services should occur in all stroke networks across
the province to support quality improvement and facilitate access to stroke care
• Ongoing education should be provided to EMS crews about the recognition of stroke/TIA symptoms and regional
medical redirect protocols
• Standardized stroke/TIA assessment and treatment protocols/tools should be developed and used in all Ontario hospital
EDs
• Upon receiving EMS prenotification, the receiving hospital’s acute stroke team should be contacted and called to the ED
(for appropriate patients)
• Sufficient human resources capacity should be ensured so that patients can be diagnosed and treated in a timely
manner
• To facilitate early assessment, hospital-level CTAS I or CTAS II access to diagnostic imaging should be established for
suspected stroke/TIA patients to facilitate early assessment
• A referral process for rapid-assessment TIA and minor stroke units/TIA clinics and provincial stroke-prevention clinics
should be established in all hospitals for patients who are not admitted to hospital
• Efforts to raise public awareness about the symptoms of stroke/TIA and when to contact 911 should continue to be
enhanced and funded
Abbreviations: CTAS, Canadian Triage and Acuity Scale; ED, emergency department; EMS, emergency medical services; TIA, transient
ischemic attack..
To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs.]

task: Module 1: Early Assessment
This module identifies best practices for the early assessment of suspected TIA or minor
(nondisabling) stroke. Patients typically present at the ED, but the same practices should be followed
at an outpatient clinic or when patients are directly admitted to acute care. The recommendations
emphasize assessing the patient to inform clinical decision-making and determine the most
appropriate pathway.
Module 1 Recommended Practices 
1.1 Initial evaluation
1.1.1 Rapid initial evaluation should be conducted for airway,
breathing, and circulation
1.2 Initial examinations
1.2.1 All patients should undergo a neurological examination to
determine focal neurological deficits and assess stroke severity on a
standardized stroke scale (NIHSS or CNS for stroke)
1.2.2 All patients should undergo brain imaging (CT or MRI)
immediately
1.2.3 Brain imaging should be interpreted immediately by a health care
provider with expertise in reading CT and/or MRI
1.2.4 All patients should undergo ECG to detect atrial fibrillation and
other acute arrhythmias
1.2.5 A chest x-ray should not delay assessment for thrombolysis 
1.2.6 All patients should have the following blood work:
• CBC
• electrolytes
• creatinine
• glucose
• INR
• partial thromboplastin time
• troponin test (if clinically indicated)
1.3 Assessment and early management of dysphagia
1.3.1 All patients with stroke should be made NPO initially and have
their swallowing ability screened using a simple, valid, reliable, bedside
testing protocol as part of their initial assessment and before initiating
oral medication, fluid, or food
1.3.2 All patients with stroke who are not alert within the first 24 hours
should be monitored closely, and swallowing ability should be
screened when clinically appropriate
1.3.3 Patients with stroke presenting with features indicating dysphagia
or pulmonary aspiration should receive a full clinical assessment of
their swallowing ability by a speech-language pathologist or
appropriately trained specialist who would advise on swallowing ability
and the required consistency of diet and fluids
1.4 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies
1.4.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged from the
ED, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary
prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)
1.5 Triage tool for patients with TIA
1.5.1 A standardized triage tool should be used to determine the
appropriate location for the care of patients with TIA
1.6 Initial examinations for TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
1.6.1 Patients with a TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke presenting
within 48 hours of symptom onset or with fluctuating motor or speech
symptoms should undergo immediate vascular imaging of the neck
arteries (carotid ultrasound, CTA, or MRA) unless the patient is clearly
not a candidate for carotid artery revascularization
1.6.2 All other patients (presenting beyond 48 hours) with a TIA or
ischemic stroke should undergo vascular imaging of the brain and
neck arteries as soon as possible
1.7 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke
Management; CBC, complete blood count; CSBPR, Canadian Best Practices Recommendations; CNS, Canadian Neurological Scale; CT,
computed tomography; CTA, computed tomography angiography; ECG, electrocardiogram; ED, emergency department; INR, international
normalized ratio; MRA, magnetic resonance angiography; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for
Chronic Conditions; NIHSS, National Institute of Health Stroke Scale; NPO, nil per os (nothing by mouth); SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate
Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.

The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.

Module 1 Implementation Considerations
General considerations
• Where feasible, EMS should divert patients to regional or district stroke centres if there is suspicion of stroke/TIA
• The process for EMS prenotification of the receiving hospital about a stroke/TIA patient arrival should be better
established to ensure acute stroke teams receive timely and detailed information
• Collaboration between local EMS and institutions that provide stroke services should occur in all stroke networks across
the province to support quality improvement and facilitate access to stroke care
• Ongoing education should be provided to EMS crews about the recognition of stroke/TIA symptoms and regional
medical redirect protocols
• Standardized stroke/TIA assessment and treatment protocols/tools should be developed and used in all Ontario hospital
EDs
• Upon receiving EMS prenotification, the receiving hospital’s acute stroke team should be contacted and called to the ED
(for appropriate patients)
• Sufficient human resources capacity should be ensured so that patients can be diagnosed and treated in a timely
manner
• To facilitate early assessment, hospital-level CTAS I or CTAS II access to diagnostic imaging should be established for
suspected stroke/TIA patients to facilitate early assessment
• A referral process for rapid-assessment TIA and minor stroke units/TIA clinics and provincial stroke-prevention clinics
should be established in all hospitals for patients who are not admitted to hospital
• Efforts to raise public awareness about the symptoms of stroke/TIA and when to contact 911 should continue to be
enhanced and funded
Abbreviations: CTAS, Canadian Triage and Acuity Scale; ED, emergency department; EMS, emergency medical services; TIA, transient
ischemic attack.
process text:
<process>
  <activity role='healthcare provider' action='Conduct rapid initial evaluation for airway, breathing, and circulation' objects='suspected TIA or minor stroke patient' id='activity1'/>
  <parallelGateway id='parallelgateway1'>
    <branch id='branch1'>
      <activity role='healthcare provider' action='Perform neurological examination and assess stroke severity using NIHSS or CNS' objects='patient' id='activity2'/>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch2'>
      <activity role='healthcare provider' action='Order brain imaging (CT or MRI)' objects='patient' id='activity3-1'/>
      <activity role='healthcare provider' action='Perform brain imaging (CT or MRI)' objects='patient' id='activity3-2'/>
      <activity role='qualified provider' action='Interpret brain imaging immediately' objects='CT or MRI results' id='activity4'/>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch3'>
      <activity role='healthcare provider' action='Perform ECG to detect atrial fibrillation and other acute arrhythmias' objects='patient' id='activity5'/>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch4'>
      <activity role='healthcare provider' action='Order blood work' objects='patient' id='activity6-1'/>
      <activity role='healthcare provider' action='Collect and process blood samples (CBC, electrolytes, creatinine, glucose, INR, partial thromboplastin time, and troponin if indicated)' objects='patient' id='activity6-2'/>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch5'>
      <activity role='healthcare provider' action='Order chest x-ray if indicated, ensuring it does not delay assessment for thrombolysis' objects='patient' id='activity7'/>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch6'>
      <activity role='healthcare provider' action='Make patient NPO initially and screen swallowing ability using bedside protocol before oral medication, fluid, or food' objects='patient' id='activity8'/>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway1'>
        <branch condition='Patient not alert within first 24 hours' id='branch7'>
          <activity role='healthcare provider' action='Monitor closely and screen swallowing ability when clinically appropriate' objects='patient' id='activity9'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Patient presents with features of dysphagia or pulmonary aspiration' id='branch8'>
          <activity role='speech-language pathologist or trained specialist' action='Conduct full clinical swallowing assessment and advise on diet/fluid consistency' objects='patient' id='activity10'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch9'>
      <activity role='healthcare provider' action='Conduct secondary prevention assessment' objects='patient' id='activity11-1'/>
      <activity role='healthcare provider' action='Initiate secondary prevention therapies' objects='patient' id='activity11-2'/>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch10'>
      <activity role='healthcare provider' action='Use standardized triage tool to determine appropriate care location for TIA patients' objects='patient' id='activity12'/>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch11'>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway2'>
        <branch condition='Patient presents within 48 hours of symptom onset or has fluctuating motor/speech symptoms' id='branch12'>
          <activity role='healthcare provider' action='Order immediate vascular imaging of neck arteries (carotid ultrasound, CTA, or MRA) unless not a candidate for revascularization' objects='patient' id='activity13'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Patient presents beyond 48 hours' id='branch13'>
          <activity role='healthcare provider' action='Order vascular imaging of brain and neck arteries as soon as possible' objects='patient' id='activity14'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
  </parallelGateway>
</process>
Please check whether there are logic problems and format problems of activities and gateways in the process text, such as the reverse of the order of activities, unreasonable design of gateways, and wrong order of activities or branches. For the modification scheme, the specific reason for modification and the details of the modification scheme should be explained.
Here's a shipping process and some examples of checking for errors, you can refer but not copy:
<process>
  <activity role='Sender' action='fill in the shipping information' objects='package, address, contact information' id='activity1'/>
  <activity role='Courier' action='receiving package' objects='package' id='activity2'/>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway1'>
    <branch condition='select pick-up' id='branch1'>
      <activity role='Sender' action='pick-up arrangement' objects='package' id='activity3'/>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='choose to send by yourself' id='branch2'>
      <activity role='Sender' action='go to the mailing point to send' objects='package,mailing point address' id='activity4'/>
    </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
  <parallelGateway id='parallelgateway1'>
    <branch id='branch3'>
      <activity role='Express company' action='packing and handling packages' objects='package' id='activity5'/>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch4'>
      <activity role='Express company' action='transport and distribution package' objects='package' id='activity6'/>
    </branch>
  </parallelGateway>
  <sequenceGateway id='sequencegateway1'>
    <activity role='Express company' action='end of service' objects='' id='activity7'/>
    <activity role='recipient' action='sign for package' objects='package' id='activity8'/>
  </sequenceGateway>
</process>
example1:
   Problem: The 'receiving package' activity with id='activity2' and the exclusive gateway with id='exclusivegateway1' are in the wrong order and logic error.
   Suggested modification: Move the 'receiving package' activity with id='activity2' under the branch with id='branch1' of the exclusive gateway with id='exclusivegateway1'.
   Reason: After the sender chooses to pick up the package, the Courier can perform the activities of accepting the package.
example2:
   Problem: The activities are not a parallel relation in the parallel gateway with id='parallelgateway1'.
   Suggested modification: In the parallel gateway with id='parallelgateway1', change the activities from a parallel structure to a sequential structure.
   Reason: Logically, 'packing and handling packages' and 'transport and distribution packages' are not parallel relationships.
example3:
   Problem: The 'end of service' activity with id='activity7' and the 'sign for parcel' activity with id='activity8' are in the wrong order.
   Suggested modification: Swap the position of the 'end of service' activity with id='activity7' and the 'sign for parcel' activity with id='activity8'.
   Reason: Only after the recipient sign for package can the express company terminate the service.
example4:
   Problem: The sequence gateway with id='sequencegateway1' is incorrectly formatted.
   Suggested modification: Remove the gateway label of the sequence gateway with id='sequencegateway1'.
   Reason: Sequential activities need not be contained under a gateway.
When making recommendations, don't forget the format of the process text:

When the process starts, please output '<process>'
An activity is represented as follows:
<activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
The exclusive gateway is represented as follows:
<exclusiveGateway id=''>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
</exclusiveGateway>
The parallel gateway is represented as follows:
<parallelGateway id=''>
  <branch id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
  <branch id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
</parallelGateway>
The inclusive gateway is represented as follows:
<inclusiveGateway id=''>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
</inclusiveGateway>
At the end of the process, please output '</process>'

There are a few requirements that should be noted when generating process text:
    1) role, action, objects and id in an activity represent the subject of the activity, the activity behavior, the items needed to perform in the activity and the activity id, respectively.
    2) There are at least two branches within the exclusive gateway and the parallel gateway.
    3) Activity, gateway, and branch id attributes must be unique.
    4) When the branch in the exclusive gateway has a condition, fill the condition into the condition attribute. When the branch unconditional within the exclusive gateway, the condition attribute of the branch =''. However, all branches within a exclusive gateway can only be conditional, or both unconditional.
    5) The branch in the parallel gateway has no condition attribute.
    6) Each branch in the inclusive gateway must have condition.
    7) There must be at least one activity inside the branch tag.
    8) The activity of a sequential relation need not be represented by a gateway, that is, there is no 'sequenceGateway' label.


Below are additional knowledge contexts to guide the process design:
1) The activity 'Provide cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies...' should be the last activity after everything else is done and before the end activity.
2) Activities related to stroke units, staffing, or hospitals in the QBP should be prioritized as the initial steps in their respective flow or branch.
3) All tests, including any type of imaging and blood tests, should be immediately interpreted by a healthcare expert.
4) Blood tests or any tests that take a long time toget results should occur concurrently with other activities unless required for a specific task, in which case they will be merged into the flow or branch of that activity.
5) Activities related to stroke units, staffing, or hospitals in the QBP should be put in a single activity.
6) Assessing airway, breathing, and circulation is called ABC testing and is ONE activity.
7) Neurological examination and imaging results are needed to Evaluate patients for endovascular therapy. However, they can be in parallel to other activities that don’ t need these results.
8) CBC, electrolytes, creatinine, glucose, INR, partial thromboplastin time, and troponin test are all types of blood tests, and they can all be in ONE blood works activity if they are at the same place of a process.
9) Anti platelet therapy has 4 general options(ASA, Clopidogrel, Extended - release Dipyridamole + Aspirin(Aggrenox), and rectal or gastric ASA if can 't swallow) and they should be indicated right after each initiation of antiplatelet therapy activity in the process. 
10) Temperature reducing activities should happen in parallel.
11) The activity 'chest x-ray should not delay...' should have a skip flow as it should be skipped if not needed.
12) If activity 'should be evaluated in the ED to be considered for admission to hospital' is needed, it should happen in parallel and not in sequence.
13) When patients should be screened / assessed for diabetes, dental issues, cognitive impairment, and depression in the same part of the process, they should be merged into one activity along with forwarding the results.
14) Assessments related and needed to formulating management plan should be merged into one activity along with formulating the management plan.
15) Formulating the management plan should happen before the activities and assessments after it.
16) Between 24 - 48 hour of stroke onset IF no contradiction, mobilization is encouraged. However, in the first 24 hour it is only encouraged IF clinical judgement suggests otherwise, it is not.

Please note:
1) If you think there is an error in the process text, output the error as requested. Please Just list one for me. 
2) If you think there is no formatting or logical error in the process text, please just output 'There is no error in the process text.' and don't say anything else.

[You're a team leader. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer.
Your main responsibilities will include guiding the process design expert through process generation, process refinement, and so on.
Here is a new customer's task: Module 1: Early Assessment
This module identifies best practices for the early assessment of suspected TIA or minor
(nondisabling) stroke. Patients typically present at the ED, but the same practices should be followed
at an outpatient clinic or when patients are directly admitted to acute care. The recommendations
emphasize assessing the patient to inform clinical decision-making and determine the most
appropriate pathway.

1.1 Initial evaluation
1.1.1 Rapid initial evaluation should be conducted for airway,
breathing, and circulation

1.2.1 All patients should undergo a neurological examination to
determine focal neurological deficits and assess stroke severity on a

1.2.2 All patients should undergo brain imaging (CT or MRI)
immediately

• CBC

• creatinine
• glucose
• INR

• troponin test (if clinically indicated)

1.5.1 A standardized triage tool should be used to determine the

1.6.1 Patients with a TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke presenting
within 48 hours of symptom onset or with fluctuating motor or speech

To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs.]

Problem: The activity 'Interpret brain imaging immediately' with id='activity4' is placed after 'Perform brain imaging (CT or MRI)' with id='activity3-2' within the same branch, but according to best practices, all test results (including imaging) should be interpreted immediately by a healthcare expert, and this interpretation should occur in parallel with other activities, not sequentially within the same branch. Additionally, the blood work activities (id='activity6-1' and id='activity6-2') are separated, but they should be merged into one blood work activity as per the guidance, and the interpretation should be included.

Suggested modification: 
1. Merge 'Order brain imaging (CT or MRI)' and 'Perform brain imaging (CT or MRI)' into a single activity, and place 'Interpret brain imaging immediately' as a parallel branch to this activity within the parallel gateway.
2. Merge 'Order blood work' and 'Collect and process blood samples...' into a single activity, and add an immediate interpretation activity as a parallel branch.
3. Ensure that all test interpretation activities are in parallel with other initial examinations, not sequential within the same branch.

Reason: This modification ensures that all test results are interpreted immediately and in parallel with other assessments, which aligns with best practices for rapid early assessment and avoids unnecessary delays in clinical decision-making. It also simplifies the process by merging related activities and ensures compliance with the requirement that all blood tests be grouped together.

[2025-30-06 23:42:46 INFO] flask app.py did not start for online log
[2025-30-06 23:42:46 INFO] **[Seminar Conclusion]**:

 Problem: The activity 'Interpret brain imaging immediately' with id='activity4' is placed after 'Perform brain imaging (CT or MRI)' with id='activity3-2' within the same branch, but according to best practices, all test results (including imaging) should be interpreted immediately by a healthcare expert, and this interpretation should occur in parallel with other activities, not sequentially within the same branch. Additionally, the blood work activities (id='activity6-1' and id='activity6-2') are separated, but they should be merged into one blood work activity as per the guidance, and the interpretation should be included.

Suggested modification: 
1. Merge 'Order brain imaging (CT or MRI)' and 'Perform brain imaging (CT or MRI)' into a single activity, and place 'Interpret brain imaging immediately' as a parallel branch to this activity within the parallel gateway.
2. Merge 'Order blood work' and 'Collect and process blood samples...' into a single activity, and add an immediate interpretation activity as a parallel branch.
3. Ensure that all test interpretation activities are in parallel with other initial examinations, not sequential within the same branch.

Reason: This modification ensures that all test results are interpreted immediately and in parallel with other assessments, which aligns with best practices for rapid early assessment and avoids unnecessary delays in clinical decision-making. It also simplifies the process by merging related activities and ensures compliance with the requirement that all blood tests be grouped together.

| **phase_prompt** | task: {task} process text:  {reviewed_process_text} suggestion: {suggestions} You need to modify the process text according to the suggestions and output it. Be careful not to change the format: {format} |
| **phase_name** | ProcessReview |
| **assistant_role_prompt** | You're a process design expert. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer. You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs. |

| **placeholders** | {'cycle_num': 10, 'max_num_implement': 2, 'description': "chat_env.env_dict['task_description']", 'reviewed_process_text': "\n  \n  \n    \n      \n    \n    \n      \n      \n      \n    \n    \n      \n    \n    \n      \n      \n    \n    \n      \n    \n    \n      \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    \n      \n      \n    \n    \n      \n    \n    \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n    \n  \n", 'cycle_index': 0, 'task': 'Module 1: Early Assessment\nThis module identifies best practices for the early assessment of suspected TIA or minor\n(nondisabling) stroke. Rapid initial evaluation should be conducted for airway,\nbreathing, and circulation\n1.2 Initial examinations\n1.2.1 All patients should undergo a neurological examination to\ndetermine focal neurological deficits and assess stroke severity on a\nstandardized stroke scale (NIHSS or CNS for stroke)\n1.2.2 All patients should undergo brain imaging (CT or MRI)\nimmediately\n1.2.3 Brain imaging should be interpreted immediately by a health care\nprovider with expertise in reading CT and/or MRI\n1.2.4 All patients should undergo ECG to detect atrial fibrillation and\nother acute arrhythmias\n1.2.5 A chest x-ray should not delay assessment for thrombolysis \n1.2.6 All patients should have the following blood work:\n• CBC\n• electrolytes\n• creatinine\n• glucose\n• INR\n• partial thromboplastin time\n• troponin test (if clinically indicated)\n1.3 Assessment and early management of dysphagia\n1.3.1 All patients with stroke should be made NPO initially and have\ntheir swallowing ability screened using a simple, valid, reliable, bedside\ntesting protocol as part of their initial assessment and before initiating\noral medication, fluid, or food\n1.3.2 All patients with stroke who are not alert within the first 24 hours\nshould be monitored closely, and swallowing ability should be\nscreened when clinically appropriate\n1.3.3 Patients with stroke presenting with features indicating dysphagia\nor pulmonary aspiration should receive a full clinical assessment of\ntheir swallowing ability by a speech-language pathologist or\nappropriately trained specialist who would advise on swallowing ability\nand the required consistency of diet and fluids\n1.4 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies\n1.4.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged from the\nED, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary\nprevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)\n1.5 Triage tool for patients with TIA\n1.5.1 A standardized triage tool should be used to determine the\nappropriate location for the care of patients with TIA\n1.6 Initial examinations for TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke\n1.6.1 Patients with a TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke presenting\nwithin 48 hours of symptom onset or with fluctuating motor or speech\nsymptoms should undergo immediate vascular imaging of the neck\narteries (carotid ultrasound, CTA, or MRA) unless the patient is clearly\nnot a candidate for carotid artery revascularization\n1.6.2 All other patients (presenting beyond 48 hours) with a TIA or\nischemic stroke should undergo vascular imaging of the brain and\nneck arteries as soon as possible\n1.7 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke\nAbbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke\nManagement; CBC, complete blood count; CSBPR, Canadian Best Practices Recommendations; CNS, Canadian Neurological Scale; CT,\ncomputed tomography; CTA, computed tomography angiography; ECG, electrocardiogram; ED, emergency department; INR, international\nnormalized ratio; MRA, magnetic resonance angiography; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for\nChronic Conditions; NIHSS, National Institute of Health Stroke Scale; NPO, nil per os (nothing by mouth); SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate\nGuidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.\n\nThe following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.\n\nModule 1 Implementation Considerations\nGeneral considerations\n• Where feasible, EMS should divert patients to regional or district stroke centres if there is suspicion of stroke/TIA\n• The process for EMS prenotification of the receiving hospital about a stroke/TIA patient arrival should be better\nestablished to ensure acute stroke teams receive timely and detailed information\n• Collaboration between local EMS and institutions that provide stroke services should occur in all stroke networks across\nthe province to support quality improvement and facilitate access to stroke care\n• Ongoing education should be provided to EMS crews about the recognition of stroke/TIA symptoms and regional\nmedical redirect protocols\n• Standardized stroke/TIA assessment and treatment protocols/tools should be developed and used in all Ontario hospital\nEDs\n• Upon receiving EMS prenotification, the receiving hospital’s acute stroke team should be contacted and called to the ED\n(for appropriate patients)\n• Sufficient human resources capacity should be ensured so that patients can be diagnosed and treated in a timely\nmanner\n• To facilitate early assessment, hospital-level CTAS I or CTAS II access to diagnostic imaging should be established for\nsuspected stroke/TIA patients to facilitate early assessment\n• A referral process for rapid-assessment TIA and minor stroke units/TIA clinics and provincial stroke-prevention clinics\nshould be established in all hospitals for patients who are not admitted to hospital\n• Efforts to raise public awareness about the symptoms of stroke/TIA and when to contact 911 should continue to be\nenhanced and funded\nAbbreviations: CTAS, Canadian Triage and Acuity Scale; ED, emergency department; EMS, emergency medical services; TIA, transient\nischemic attack.', 'suggestions': "Problem: The activity 'Interpret brain imaging immediately' with id='activity4' is placed after 'Perform brain imaging (CT or MRI)' with id='activity3-2' within the same branch, but according to best practices, all test results (including imaging) should be interpreted immediately by a healthcare expert, and this interpretation should occur in parallel with other activities, not sequentially within the same branch. Additionally, the blood work activities (id='activity6-1' and id='activity6-2') are separated, but they should be merged into one blood work activity as per the guidance, and the interpretation should be included.\n\nSuggested modification: \n1. Merge 'Order brain imaging (CT or MRI)' and 'Perform brain imaging (CT or MRI)' into a single activity, and place 'Interpret brain imaging immediately' as a parallel branch to this activity within the parallel gateway.\n2. Merge 'Order blood work' and 'Collect and process blood samples...' into a single activity, and add an immediate interpretation activity as a parallel branch.\n3. Ensure that all test interpretation activities are in parallel with other initial examinations, not sequential within the same branch.\n\nReason: This modification ensures that all test results are interpreted immediately and in parallel with other assessments, which aligns with best practices for rapid early assessment and avoids unnecessary delays in clinical decision-making. It also simplifies the process by merging related activities and ensures compliance with the requirement that all blood tests be grouped together.", 'format': "\nWhen the process starts, please output ''\nAn activity is represented as follows:\n\nThe exclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe parallel gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe inclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nAt the end of the process, please output ''\n\nThere are a few requirements that should be noted when generating process text:\n    1) role, action, objects and id in an activity represent the subject of the activity, the activity behavior, the items needed to perform in the activity and the activity id, respectively.\n    2) There are at least two branches within the exclusive gateway and the parallel gateway.\n    3) Activity, gateway, and branch id attributes must be unique.\n    4) When the branch in the exclusive gateway has a condition, fill the condition into the condition attribute. When the branch unconditional within the exclusive gateway, the condition attribute of the branch =''. However, all branches within a exclusive gateway can only be conditional, or both unconditional.\n    5) The branch in the parallel gateway has no condition attribute.\n    6) Each branch in the inclusive gateway must have condition.\n    7) There must be at least one activity inside the branch tag.\n    8) The activity of a sequential relation need not be represented by a gateway, that is, there is no 'sequenceGateway' label.\n", 'examples': ' '} |

| **user_role_prompt** | You're a process design reviewer. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer. You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. Your main responsibilities include give suggestion to the process. Here is a new customer's task: {task}. To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs. |
| **task_prompt** | Module 1: Early Assessment This module identifies best practices for the early assessment of suspected TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke. Patients typically present at the ED, but the same practices should be followed at an outpatient clinic or when patients are directly admitted to acute care. The recommendations emphasize assessing the patient to inform clinical decision-making and determine the most appropriate pathway. Module 1 Recommended Practices  1.1 Initial evaluation 1.1.1 Rapid initial evaluation should be conducted for airway, breathing, and circulation 1.2 Initial examinations 1.2.1 All patients should undergo a neurological examination to determine focal neurological deficits and assess stroke severity on a standardized stroke scale (NIHSS or CNS for stroke) 1.2.2 All patients should undergo brain imaging (CT or MRI) immediately 1.2.3 Brain imaging should be interpreted immediately by a health care provider with expertise in reading CT and/or MRI 1.2.4 All patients should undergo ECG to detect atrial fibrillation and other acute arrhythmias 1.2.5 A chest x-ray should not delay assessment for thrombolysis  1.2.6 All patients should have the following blood work: • CBC • electrolytes • creatinine • glucose • INR • partial thromboplastin time • troponin test (if clinically indicated) 1.3 Assessment and early management of dysphagia 1.3.1 All patients with stroke should be made NPO initially and have their swallowing ability screened using a simple, valid, reliable, bedside testing protocol as part of their initial assessment and before initiating oral medication, fluid, or food 1.3.2 All patients with stroke who are not alert within the first 24 hours should be monitored closely, and swallowing ability should be screened when clinically appropriate 1.3.3 Patients with stroke presenting with features indicating dysphagia or pulmonary aspiration should receive a full clinical assessment of their swallowing ability by a speech-language pathologist or appropriately trained specialist who would advise on swallowing ability and the required consistency of diet and fluids 1.4 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies 1.4.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged from the ED, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10) 1.5 Triage tool for patients with TIA 1.5.1 A standardized triage tool should be used to determine the appropriate location for the care of patients with TIA 1.6 Initial examinations for TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke 1.6.1 Patients with a TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke presenting within 48 hours of symptom onset or with fluctuating motor or speech symptoms should undergo immediate vascular imaging of the neck arteries (carotid ultrasound, CTA, or MRA) unless the patient is clearly not a candidate for carotid artery revascularization 1.6.2 All other patients (presenting beyond 48 hours) with a TIA or ischemic stroke should undergo vascular imaging of the brain and neck arteries as soon as possible 1.7 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management; CBC, complete blood count; CSBPR, Canadian Best Practices Recommendations; CNS, Canadian Neurological Scale; CT, computed tomography; CTA, computed tomography angiography; ECG, electrocardiogram; ED, emergency department; INR, international normalized ratio; MRA, magnetic resonance angiography; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; NIHSS, National Institute of Health Stroke Scale; NPO, nil per os (nothing by mouth); SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack. The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel. Module 1 Implementation Considerations General considerations • Where feasible, EMS should divert patients to regional or district stroke centres if there is suspicion of stroke/TIA • The process for EMS prenotification of the receiving hospital about a stroke/TIA patient arrival should be better established to ensure acute stroke teams receive timely and detailed information • Collaboration between local EMS and institutions that provide stroke services should occur in all stroke networks across the province to support quality improvement and facilitate access to stroke care • Ongoing education should be provided to EMS crews about the recognition of stroke/TIA symptoms and regional medical redirect protocols • Standardized stroke/TIA assessment and treatment protocols/tools should be developed and used in all Ontario hospital EDs • Upon receiving EMS prenotification, the receiving hospital’s acute stroke team should be contacted and called to the ED (for appropriate patients) • Sufficient human resources capacity should be ensured so that patients can be diagnosed and treated in a timely manner • To facilitate early assessment, hospital-level CTAS I or CTAS II access to diagnostic imaging should be established for suspected stroke/TIA patients to facilitate early assessment • A referral process for rapid-assessment TIA and minor stroke units/TIA clinics and provincial stroke-prevention clinics should be established in all hospitals for patients who are not admitted to hospital • Efforts to raise public awareness about the symptoms of stroke/TIA and when to contact 911 should continue to be enhanced and funded Abbreviations: CTAS, Canadian Triage and Acuity Scale; ED, emergency department; EMS, emergency medical services; TIA, transient ischemic attack. |
| **with_task_specify** | False |
| **memory** | current memory not loaded |

SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate\nGuidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.\n\nThe following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.\n\nModule 1 prenotification of the receiving hospital about a stroke/TIA patient arrival should be better\nestablished to ensure acute stroke teams receive timely and detailed information\n• Collaboration between should be developed and used in all Ontario hospital\nEDs\n• Upon receiving EMS prenotification, the receiving hospital’s acute stroke team should be contacted and called to the ED\n(for appropriate patients)\n• Sufficient human resources capacity should be ensured so that patients can be diagnosed and treated in a timely\nmanner\n• To facilitate early assessment, hospital-level CTAS I or CTAS II access to diagnostic imaging should be established for\nsuspected stroke/TIA patients to facilitate early assessment\n• A referral process for rapid-assessment TIA and minor stroke units/TIA clinics and provincial stroke-prevention clinics\nshould be established in all hospitals for patients who are not admitted to hospital\n• Efforts to raise public awareness about the symptoms of stroke/TIA and when to contact 911 should continue to be\nenhanced and funded\nAbbreviations: CTAS, Canadian Triage and Acuity Scale; ED, emergency department; EMS, emergency medical services; TIA, within the same branch, but according to best practices, all test results (including imaging) should be interpreted immediately by a healthcare expert, and this interpretation should occur in parallel with other activities, not sequentially within the same branch. Additionally, the blood work activities (id='activity6-1' and id='activity6-2') are separated, but they should be merged into one blood work activity as per the guidance, and the interpretation should be included.\n\nSuggested modification: \n1. Merge 'Order blood work' and 'Collect and process blood samples...' into a single activity, and add an immediate interpretation activity as a parallel branch.\n3.
